This text was transcribed using whisper model: large-v2

 Welcome to a Decepticon and Autobot walk into a bar.
This is a new Python tool for Enhanced OpSec.
I'm Joe Gray, coming to you from almost on the other side of the world.
I'm here in the United States.
So this is going to be a project that I took on
to enhance my own comprehension and understanding of both Python,
artificial intelligence to a degree, machine learning, and natural language processing.
I wrapped it all up in a way that will allow a positive outcome to occur.
So I'm going to go ahead and kill my camera now,
since I've been told that I have a face made for radio.
That continuing, about me by day, I'm a senior OSINT specialist complex.
I have some experience with Python scripting.
I'm incredibly interested in the data sciences, as I stated previously.
I do frequently compete in the Trace Labs OSINT search party,
or missing person CTF, whichever you know it by.
My team, the password inspection agency, actually just won
the last competition that occurred as part of DEFCON.
With that, with a lot of what I do regarding OSINT,
I look at the yin to the yang of OSINT, which would be OPSEC.
I also have advisory volunteer roles with
both the National Child Protection Task Force and Operation Safe Escape.
Operation Safe Escape being in bold because,
honestly, that's the organization that benefits most from DEFECON.
A few things that I'm not.
I'm not a programmer or developer in nature.
I'm by far not a mathematician or a data scientist,
nor am I an expert when talking about things
dealing with trafficking or domestic violence.
It's something that I'm concerned with.
It's something that I definitely have interest in making a positive outcome,
but I'm by no stretch of the imagination an expert.
Before we get started, I have a few definitions for us to go over,
just so that we can level the playing field
with everything that will be talked about in this presentation.
First, we have OSINT, open source intelligence.
That's basically information gathered from public sources
in an intelligence context.
We have OPSEC, operation security.
Basically, that's taking steps to obscure, hide, or masquerade
information about you and what you are doing
so that adversaries or other concerned parties
will have trouble finding you or making any determinations
in terms of the reliability of the data.
I'm a huge fan of implementing disinformation and deception through that.
In fact, implementing disinformation and deception
to enhance your OPSEC, I've been calling that Decepticon
for the last couple of years since the name of the bot.
Machine learning, that's just the study of math and algorithms
to improve the automation via learning, if you will,
so that it assists us in developing algorithms
to be able to learn, if you will,
based on the outcome of the data.
We can also do predictions and decisions based on that.
With Decepticon, it's mostly focusing on predictions.
Data science is an amalgam of several disciplines
that seeks to study the relationship between
data structures and the processes and algorithms
to help us gain insight from the data.
I like to think of it from the perspective of
data science seeks to identify patterns
that are not visible to the human eye or the human mind.
We have artificial intelligence.
Yes, I will admit that's a term that has been kind of ruined by vendors as of late,
but it's the study of intelligence shown by machines and programs
to attempt to mimic that natural intelligence.
Natural intelligence being the intelligence shown by humans or animals.
Then finally, we've got GPU.
That's the graphics processing unit.
It's a specialized system on board many computers.
In fact, any computer that has any sort of graphics has one,
but in this scenario, we're using it to accelerate the processing of images or video.
More specifically, it's used within machine learning to speed up processing.
NVIDIA has some really cool toys for that.
The problem, one of the leading ways that adversaries find their way
into the lives or back into their lives of their victims is social media.
What is an adversary?
That could be a malicious person seeking financial gain.
That could be someone just seeking to harm someone else.
Abusers, traffickers, political opponents will do that.
In the United States, we've got the possible apocalypse coming up
on the first Tuesday in November with the election.
I really hate to toss the term nation state out,
but depending on the person's threat profile,
a nation state could legitimately be an adversary for them.
Then you also have what I call adversaries of opportunity.
That would be in the case where someone has really bad OPSEC
and the adversary is just out there looking and just happens to come across
that particular person and notices,
hey, this account is hemorrhaging information.
Let's exploit it and see what we can get from it.
When we talk about victims that could be public figures,
such as politicians or executives,
obviously there are some companies out there
whose executives are universally a target
because of what the company does or who the company does business with.
Then we have victims of domestic abuse and or trafficking.
Many times they don't have much say so in the matter whatsoever.
Then we also have people with poor or misguided OPSEC.
For example, I was debating with a friend from when I was in the Navy
on Facebook a while back about privacy.
He's like, oh, I don't have to worry about this.
I use a VPN.
I was like, oh, cool, which one?
He's like, oh, it's a free one.
It's this.
I don't recall what it was exactly.
I pointed out that with a VPN especially,
that's one of the products that you definitely want to pay for
because you have some expectation of support.
That's not to say that your data won't get sold,
but you have a more legitimate claim when it comes to that.
Oftentimes, if you don't pay for the product, you are the product.
References for that, see Facebook and Google.
Thankfully, for many of you, you're subjected to GDPR,
so you have a certain level of privacy and protection that I only wish I had.
To be honest, had COVID not happened
and I had actually traveled to Gdynia for the conference,
I was going to hop on to some Wi-Fi connections around the area
and use the right to be forgotten
because what I've learned is many platforms,
when you go to opt out of things,
they don't do any validation checking to verify you're a citizen of the European Union.
They just look at the IP address.
Oh, well, this is coming from the EU, so I'm kind of bummed about that,
but life goes on and there's always next year,
and if not next year, the year after,
and eventually it will become safe for us to all travel again.
So after I rebutted that to my friend,
he was like, well, I use this DNS service as well.

If you're doing certain things, you might want to use Tor.
You may want to do this.
You may want to do that.
And it turned into a really good private conversation between my friend and I.
And he learned a lot and I learned quite a bit myself.
So as we dissect some advice from an OPSEC perspective,
if someone's being harassed or stalked,
some of the advice I've seen tossed around is, well, just abandon the account.
Well, that's not always feasible, to be honest.
And with that being said,
it could cue the adversary that the account has been abandoned.
It could also lead them to go looking for alternative accounts.
And if someone's using accounts that doesn't have the person's real name on it,
especially with Facebook,
I don't know if this is something that you encounter in Europe,
but in the United States,
if you create a Facebook account
and they don't believe you're using your real name,
they will prompt you for a driver's license.
And if you don't want to provide that,
they just straight up shut the account down.

and creates an account under a fake name,
a fictitious name,
then that person could report the account.
If they reported enough,
then that account will be prompted for submitting some form of identification.
And when they fail to do so,
the account gets burned.
Let's face it.
Some people have to use social media for work.
Me working in the OSINT field,
I have to use social media for work.
That also being said,
I don't have to use legitimate accounts.
Whereas some people have to use legitimate accounts
either to interact with customers
or to run a business page or something to that effect.
And I mean, I'm just going to be real here.
Why should a victim live in fear?
Because someone cannot respect their wishes and their privacy.
And at the same time,
some victims just are not aware of the adversary until it's too late.
So continuing to dissect this,
if the abuser wants to continue trauma,
they can create fake accounts of their own.
They may leverage friends or friends of friends
that may have access to see the victim's posts.
As I stated before,
they may report those alternative accounts for being fake.
There was a case just about a week or two ago.
There was a young man,
a college student in India who published a Medium article
talking about how he had a crush that ghosted him 10 years ago.

they heavily advocated the use of pandas.

So within the code, Keras is used to implement a long short-term memory model,
which is used to predict sequences of the text and then thus generate the text.
So it's a long short-term memory model.
In short, it's a type of recurrent neural network.
More specifically, a neural network, not too far,
a recurrent neural network is something that takes past decisions into mind
and that's going to influence the outcome with that.
They can also remember previous things learned.
So in order to do that, if the model is not actively running,
you just have to save it to a specific file
so that it can be reloaded the next time that the code runs
and the model needs to execute.
The reason these are very useful for things like text, speech, and images
is that a recurrent neural network is not of a fixed vector size.
And as we know, within natural speech, we don't have fixed vectors.
For example, if I greet you, you may say,
hello, good morning, good afternoon, how are you?
Get out of my face.
All of those things have different lengths, different characters,
different lengths of words.
So we can't say there's a fixed vector size for that.
So a long short-term memory model in that specific vein
seeks to learn order dependencies and do sequence prediction.
So that's very important for generating text.
And honestly, it doesn't even care what language the text is in.
So you could, I've not tested this, but you could put it against
text from any language, and it should be able to do that same
order of dependencies and sequence prediction.

that makes LSTMs very lucrative for natural language processing.
